interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course integrates Business and Economics (hospitality/tourism management) with Social Sciences (sustainability, ethics, global development) and Natural Sciences (environmental performance, resource management). Learning outcomes explicitly address UN Sustainable Development Goals, triple bottom line analysis (economic, social, environmental), and consumer behavior alongside environmental metrics like greenhouse gas emissions and energy/water/waste management. This represents genuine cross-domain integration where business decisions are analyzed through environmental and social frameworks.

undergraduate_research.rationale: Students complete individual research projects involving 'business briefs and video reports based on their research into a chosen topic' (200 points). The group project requires students to 'undertake a Sustainable Tourism and Hospitality project' including 'recommendation on a practical issue' with evaluation of recommendations. These involve formulation of questions, analysis of evidence, and production of original applied findings.

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The course explicitly addresses 'tourism and the UN Sustainable Development Goals/Grand Challenges' (Learning Outcome 2) and 'leadership principles to manage in a diverse and global business environment' (PLO2). Course content covers destination communities, responsible travel, and consumer issues in sustainability. The group project addresses 'a practical issue sustainable hospitality issue' suggesting application to real-world contexts, with structured reflection on ethical dimensions (Learning Outcome 7 on ethics).

leadership_development.rationale: Learning Outcome 7 explicitly addresses 'principles of ethics as applied to the tourism industry.' PLO2 requires students to 'apply leadership principles to manage in a diverse and global business environment.' PLO4 requires students to 'demonstrate the ability to define, identify, and evaluate ethical versus unethical business practices.' The group project requires recommendation development and evaluation, involving decision-making with professional consequences.

advanced_content.rationale: The course is a 300-level upper-division course covering advanced topics including sustainability management systems (Earthcheck case studies), UN Sustainable Development Goals, triple bottom line analysis, greenhouse gas accounting, benchmarking, and sector-specific sustainability programs. Learning outcomes require students to analyze and evaluate programs, not just describe them.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: The Earthcheck case studies involve 10 sequential exercises across the semester (EC1-EC10) building from policy through activity measures, energy, water, waste, benchmarking, and GHG analysis. The individual project has multiple stages (topic selection, draft, report, video plan, video submission). The group project progresses through problem identification, research draft, recommendations, and preliminary evaluation.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The course requires both significant independent work (Individual Projects/Business Briefs worth 200 points involving self-directed research) and collaborative work (Group Project worth 220 points). Discovery Learning Exercises (220 points) involve in-class and online activities. The teaching philosophy explicitly states students are 'encouraged to engage in the course by following their personal interests within the framework of the course.'

student_defined_projects.rationale: Individual projects allow students to complete 'a business brief and a video report based on their research into a chosen topic.' The teaching philosophy explicitly encourages students 'to engage in the course by following their personal interests within the framework of the course, so that the course provides an opportunity for students to explore areas of the topic through self-directed research and study.'

consequential_decision_making.rationale: The group project requires students to develop 'recommendation on a practical issue sustainable hospitality issue' with 'evaluation of the recommendation' reported at semester end. Learning outcomes require students to 'analyze sustainability programs in various tourism sectors to determine their effectiveness' and 'apply and evaluate environmental performance programs,' involving professional judgment with real-world implications.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: Multiple major assignments require iterative development: Individual Project has topic selection (Sept 21), draft (Oct 5), report (Oct 19), video plan (Nov 9), and final video (Nov 23). Group Project progresses through problem identification (Sept 21), research draft (Oct 5), recommendations (Oct 26), and preliminary evaluation (Dec 7). Earthcheck cases involve 10 progressive exercises across the semester.

major_project.rationale: The course includes multiple major projects: Individual Projects/Business Briefs (200 points, 20% of grade), Group Project (220 points, 22% of grade), and Earthcheck Case Studies (200 points, 20% of grade). Each constitutes a significant portion of the course grade and requires sustained intellectual work.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: While there are multiple projects throughout the semester, there is no explicit portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates work across the term into a single comprehensive assessment.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: The individual project culminates in 'a video report' that is a public-facing format. The group project involves 'recommendation on a practical issue sustainable hospitality issue' suggesting application-oriented outcomes requiring academic judgment.

sustained_assessment.rationale: The majority of graded work requires critical analysis and original contribution: Earthcheck Case Studies (200 points), Individual Projects (200 points), Group Project (220 points), and Discovery Learning Exercises (220 points) total 640 points out of 1000, representing 64% of the grade. These all require analysis, synthesis, or application rather than simple recall.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: HTM 37000 is a 300-level upper-division course, not a lower-division introductory course.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: While the course covers various sectors (destinations, lodging, restaurants, meetings, transportation), it does so through the focused lens of sustainability analysis and requires advanced analytical work including evaluation of programs and development of recommendations, not just broad coverage.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: The course emphasizes conceptual understanding of sustainability, ethical analysis, and application of frameworks. The Earthcheck exercises involve using sustainability management tools, but within a broader analytical and evaluative context, not as standalone tool training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes multiple major deliverables: Individual Projects/Business Briefs (200 points), Group Project (220 points), and Earthcheck Case Studies (200 points), each representing significant intellectual work.

already_counted.rationale: No evidence in the syllabus suggests this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets all four Honors pillars (interdisciplinary academics through business-social science-natural science integration; undergraduate research through individual and group projects; community and global engagement through UN SDGs and practical sustainability issues; leadership development through ethics and decision-making). It satisfies all rigor criteria (advanced content, sustained inquiry, independent and collaborative work), all student agency criteria (student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, extended analytical commitment), and demonstrates clear evidence of learning through major projects, public-facing outcomes, and sustained assessment requiring critical analysis. No exclusions apply.

interdisciplinary_academics.rationale: The course focuses exclusively on hospitality and tourism research within a single domain. There is no evidence of integration with another high-level knowledge domain such as Engineering, Natural Sciences, Humanities, or Education.

undergraduate_research.rationale: The course explicitly engages students in original research activities including 'formulation of a research plan, data collection, assessment of data quality, and interpretation based on available data,' and students 'collect original data and contribute to problem solving in hospitality and tourism.'

community_and_global_engagement.rationale: The syllabus does not describe sustained engagement with communities, organizations, or global issues, nor does it include structured reflection on ethical, social, or cultural dimensions of such engagement.

leadership_development.rationale: There is no evidence of intentional leadership development, decision-making practice with responsibility for outcomes, or analysis of leadership or ethical frameworks.

advanced_content.rationale: The course includes advanced research methods such as 'literature reviews, data collection, coding, and data analysis,' and covers components like research design, autoethnography, and theory, indicating advanced analytical and methodological content.

sustained_inquiry.rationale: Students engage in sustained research inquiry across the semester, from formulating research questions through data collection to writing multiple drafts of a research paper or proposal.

independent_or_collaborative_work.rationale: The course requires significant independent research work under faculty supervision, including weekly research activities and a semester-long research project with iterative drafts.

student_defined_projects.rationale: The deliverable is 'based on an agreement with the professor' and can include 'writing a research proposal, presenting research to an audience, carrying out a study, etc.,' indicating student input in defining the project scope.

consequential_decision_making.rationale: Students formulate research questions, design studies, and make methodological decisions throughout the research process, which have intellectual consequences for the validity and interpretation of their findings.

extended_analytical_commitment.rationale: The course schedule shows iterative work with multiple drafts (First Draft, Second Draft, Final Draft) indicating extended analytical commitment and revision based on feedback.

major_project.rationale: The Research Project (25% of grade) requires students to produce a research paper or comprehensive reflection paper, constituting a significant portion of the course grade.

portfolio_or_capstone.rationale: There is no evidence of a portfolio or capstone-style artifact that integrates multiple pieces of work across the term.

public_facing_outcome.rationale: While a presentation is mentioned as one possible deliverable option, there is no clear requirement for public-facing or applied outcomes requiring academic judgment.

sustained_assessment.rationale: Research Activities constitute 75% of the grade with weekly readings, discussions, and participation in research tasks (literature reviews, data collection, coding, analysis), indicating sustained assessment requiring critical analysis throughout the term.

lower_division_introductory.rationale: This is a 39001-level course designed as a research experience, not a lower-division introductory course.

broad_introductory_coverage.rationale: The course is focused on research methodology and conducting original research, not broad introductory coverage of hospitality concepts.

skills_only_or_tool_training.rationale: While research skills are taught, they are applied within a sustained research project with intellectual deliverables, not merely tool training.

lacks_major_deliverable.rationale: The course includes a major research project (25% of grade) that requires either a research paper or comprehensive reflection on the research process.

already_counted.rationale: There is no evidence in the syllabus that this course is already counted through another Honors credit mechanism.

review_decision.rationale: The course meets the undergraduate_research pillar by engaging students in original inquiry and knowledge creation. It satisfies all rigor requirements (advanced content, sustained inquiry, independent work), all student agency requirements (student-defined projects, consequential decision-making, extended analytical commitment), and demonstrable evidence requirements (major project, sustained assessment). No exclusions apply.
